example_1: I'm staying home today because I'm a bit under the weather.
example_2: She looked under the weather, so we told her to rest.
when_to_use: Use when describing mild sickness, fatigue, or general unwellness in casual conversation.

meaning: behaving in a strange or crazy way
example_1: People say he's got bats in the belfry, but he's just creative.
example_2: If you think that plan will work, you must have bats in the belfry.
when_to_use: Use humorously or playfully when someone's behavior or ideas seem odd or irrational, often in older or literary-style English.

meaning: searching for information without a clear target
example_1: The detective seemed to be on a fishing expedition, asking random questions.
example_2: Her questions felt like a fishing expedition for gossip.
when_to_use: Use when someone is trying to get information without saying exactly what they want, especially in legal, investigative, or gossip contexts.

meaning: showing exaggerated moral shock or outrage
example_1: There was a lot of pearl clutching over the racy TV scene.
example_2: Online commenters were pearl clutching about the meme.
when_to_use: Use when people dramatically act offended or scandalized, often about something minor or modern social issues.

example_1: Coffee shops are a dime a dozen in this neighborhood.
example_2: Good ideas are a dime a dozen; execution is what matters.
when_to_use: Use when describing something that is so common or easily found that it is not particularly valuable or impressive.

example_1: Stop beating around the bush and tell me what you want.
example_2: He kept beating around the bush instead of answering.
when_to_use: Use when someone is avoiding a direct answer or trying not to talk about a specific topic.

meaning: force yourself to do something difficult or unpleasant
example_1: I finally bit the bullet and went to the dentist.
example_2: She bit the bullet and apologized.
when_to_use: Use when someone decides to finally do something uncomfortable, scary, or unpleasant that they've been avoiding.

meaning: a way to wish someone good luck
example_1: You‚Äôve got this audition‚Äîbreak a leg!
example_2: The director told the cast to break a leg before the show.
when_to_use: Use (especially in theatre or performance contexts) when wishing someone good luck before they do something important or public.

example_1: We‚Äôre tired; let‚Äôs call it a day.
example_2: After ten hours of driving, we called it a day.
when_to_use: Use when you decide to stop working or doing an activity, usually because you're tired or have done enough.

meaning: do something in a cheap or lazy way that harms quality
example_1: They cut corners when building the house and now there are leaks.
example_2: Don‚Äôt cut corners on safety procedures.
when_to_use: Use when someone takes shortcuts that reduce quality, safety, or thoroughness to save time or money.

meaning: go to bed or go to sleep
example_1: I'm exhausted; I'm going to hit the sack.
example_2: We hit the sack early after the long hike.
when_to_use: Use informally when you are going to bed or talking about someone going to sleep.

example_1: Relax, I'm just pulling your leg.
example_2: He said he won the lottery, but he was only pulling my leg.
when_to_use: Use when you want to say that something you said was just a joke or light teasing, not serious.

phrase: let the cat out of the bag
meaning: reveal a secret, often by accident
example_1: She let the cat out of the bag about the surprise party.
example_2: Don't let the cat out of the bag before Friday.
when_to_use: Use when someone reveals information that was supposed to stay secret, especially about surprises or plans.

example_1: The exam was a piece of cake.
example_2: Fixing that bug will be a piece of cake for you.
when_to_use: Use when a task or challenge is much easier than expected or needs very little effort.

meaning: do something to reduce tension or awkwardness
example_1: He told a joke to break the ice at the meeting.
example_2: Games can help break the ice at parties.
when_to_use: Use when talking about starting a conversation or doing something to make people feel more comfortable in a new or awkward situation.

phrase: cost an arm and a leg
example_1: That car cost an arm and a leg.
example_2: The vacation will cost an arm and a leg if we‚Äôre not careful.
when_to_use: Use when describing something that is much more expensive than you would like or expect.

phrase: hit the nail on the head
example_1: You hit the nail on the head with that comment.
example_2: Her analysis hit the nail on the head.
when_to_use: Use when someone expresses the exact truth or correct explanation of a situation.

example_1: We see each other once in a blue moon.
example_2: He only eats dessert once in a blue moon.
when_to_use: Use when something happens so infrequently that it's almost surprising when it does occur.

example_1: Who spilled the beans about the promotion?
example_2: Don‚Äôt spill the beans about our plan.
when_to_use: Use when someone reveals confidential or surprise information that was supposed to stay hidden.

meaning: get to the main point quickly
example_1: Let‚Äôs cut to the chase and talk about the budget.
example_2: He cut to the chase and asked for a raise.
when_to_use: Use when you want someone to stop giving background information and speak about the main issue directly.

meaning: up to the last possible moment
example_1: The game went down to the wire.
example_2: Negotiations went down to the wire before they agreed.
when_to_use: Use when something (like a game, project, or decision) is not decided until the very last moments.

example_1: We sat on the porch and chewed the fat all evening.
example_2: They love to chew the fat over coffee.
when_to_use: Use informally when describing relaxed, unhurried conversation, often in older or rural-style English.

example_1: Yelling at him only added fuel to the fire.
example_2: Gossiping will add fuel to the fire of this argument.
when_to_use: Use when an action or comment makes an already tense or bad situation even more intense.

phrase: if the shoe fits, wear it
meaning: if a criticism applies to you, accept it
example_1: He didn‚Äôt name names, but if the shoe fits, wear it.
example_2: I wasn‚Äôt talking about you, unless the shoe fits.
synonyms: if it applies to you, accept it
if it's true for you, own it
when_to_use: Use when someone feels attacked by a general criticism and you suggest they only take it personally if it truly applies.

meaning: waste time being upset about something that can't be changed
example_1: It's done‚Äîno use crying over spilled milk.
example_2: He keeps crying over spilled milk instead of moving on.
when_to_use: Use when someone is upset about a past mistake or problem that can't be fixed anymore.

example_1: We should hit the road before traffic gets bad.
example_2: They hit the road at dawn to avoid the heat.
when_to_use: Use informally when you are leaving a place or beginning a trip or journey.

example_1: He joked that his old laptop finally kicked the bucket.
example_2: The plant kicked the bucket when we forgot to water it.
when_to_use: Use jokingly or humorously, often about death (of people, pets, or objects) in a light, not serious tone.

example_1: Just let sleeping dogs lie and don‚Äôt mention it again.
example_2: He decided to let sleeping dogs lie rather than reopen the debate.
when_to_use: Use when it's better not to mention an old problem or argument again because it may cause more trouble.

example_1: She hit the jackpot with that new job.
example_2: We hit the jackpot finding such a cheap apartment.
when_to_use: Use when someone experiences big success or luck, especially unexpectedly.

meaning: being very careful not to upset someone
example_1: Everyone is walking on eggshells around the boss today.
example_2: I feel like I‚Äôm walking on eggshells when he‚Äôs in a bad mood.
when_to_use: Use when people feel they must be extremely careful with words or actions around someone who is sensitive or easily angered.

example_1: I had to bite my tongue to keep from laughing.
example_2: She bit her tongue instead of saying something rude.
when_to_use: Use when you want to say that you stopped yourself from speaking, especially to avoid being rude or causing trouble.

meaning: suddenly and completely stop a habit
example_1: He quit smoking cold turkey.
example_2: She went cold turkey on social media for a month.
when_to_use: Use when someone stops a habit (often an addiction) suddenly, without slowly reducing it.

example_1: After years of trying, he threw in the towel.
example_2: She almost threw in the towel on her thesis.
when_to_use: Use when someone decides to stop trying to succeed at something because it feels too difficult or hopeless.

example_1: We need to talk about the elephant in the room: our budget.
example_2: The elephant in the room was his sudden absence.
synonyms: thing no one wants to mention
when_to_use: Use when there is a major issue everyone is aware of, but no one wants to talk about directly.

meaning: the final problem that makes a situation unbearable
example_1: The missed payment was the last straw.
example_2: His rude comment was the last straw for her.
synonyms: what pushed me over the edge
when_to_use: Use when one final small problem makes someone lose patience after many previous problems.

example_1: That trip won‚Äôt break the bank if we plan ahead.
example_2: The repairs nearly broke the bank.
when_to_use: Use when something costs a lot of money, especially more than you can comfortably afford.

meaning: join something because it is popular
example_1: Everyone‚Äôs jumping on the bandwagon with that new app.
example_2: He jumped on the bandwagon once the trend went viral.
when_to_use: Use when someone joins an activity, idea, or trend mainly because many other people are doing it.

meaning: wait patiently and take no action
example_1: Just sit tight while we fix the issue.
example_2: The doctor told us to sit tight and wait for the results.
when_to_use: Use when you want someone to wait calmly and not do anything until more information comes.

example_1: Your glasses are right under your nose.
example_2: The answer was under our noses the whole time.
when_to_use: Use when something that is being searched for is actually very close and easy to see.

phrase: the ball is in your court
meaning: it is your turn or responsibility to act
example_1: I‚Äôve done my part; now the ball is in your court.
example_2: The ball is in your court‚Äîdecide what you want to do.
when_to_use: Use when you have done what you can, and now another person must decide or act.

meaning: caught in the act of doing something wrong
example_1: He was caught red-handed stealing cookies.
example_2: They caught her red-handed changing the numbers.
when_to_use: Use when someone is discovered doing something wrong at the exact moment they are doing it.

example_1: They paid him under the table for extra work.
example_2: The deal was done under the table.
when_to_use: Use when something (usually money or deals) is done secretly and not recorded officially, often against the rules.

phrase: get your ducks in a row
example_1: You need to get your ducks in a row before the meeting.
example_2: She spent the afternoon getting her ducks in a row for the trip.
when_to_use: Use when you need to prepare and organize tasks or information before something important happens.

example_1: We burned the midnight oil studying for exams.
example_2: He‚Äôs been burning the midnight oil to finish his project.
when_to_use: Use when someone is working very late at night, usually to meet a deadline or finish something important.

meaning: betray or sacrifice someone to save yourself
example_1: He threw his colleague under the bus to impress the boss.
example_2: She refused to throw her team under the bus.
when_to_use: Use when someone unfairly blames or sacrifices another person to protect themselves or gain an advantage.

example_1: I don‚Äôt mean to rain on your parade, but it might storm.
example_2: Her criticism really rained on his parade.
when_to_use: Use when something spoils someone‚Äôs excitement, joy, or plans.

example_1: They went the whole nine yards with the wedding decorations.
example_2: If we‚Äôre doing this, let‚Äôs go the whole nine yards.
when_to_use: Use when someone does something completely or to the maximum extent, not halfway.

meaning: no longer in trouble or no longer responsible
example_1: Looks like you‚Äôre off the hook; they found the mistake.
example_2: The rain got us off the hook from mowing the lawn.
when_to_use: Use when someone is freed from blame, punishment, or an obligation.

example_1: She hit the ground running in her new role.
example_2: The team hit the ground running after the kickoff meeting.
when_to_use: Use when someone starts a new job, project, or task with energy, efficiency, and immediate productivity.

example_1: Our travel plans are still up in the air.
example_2: The decision is up in the air until next week.
when_to_use: Use when something (like plans or decisions) has not been finalized yet.

meaning: keep going and don‚Äôt give up
example_1: Hang in there; things will improve.
example_2: She told me to hang in there during exam season.
when_to_use: Use to encourage someone who is going through something difficult but needs to keep trying.

example_1: You‚Äôre late, but it‚Äôs no biggie.
example_2: It‚Äôs no biggie if we reschedule.
when_to_use: Use casually to say that something is not serious or not worth worrying about.

meaning: my mistake; I am to blame
example_1: Oops, my bad‚ÄîI sent the wrong file.
example_2: I forgot to call you back, my bad.
when_to_use: Use in informal situations to admit a small mistake and take responsibility.

example_1: You need to chill out and take a break.
example_2: We just chilled out at home all weekend.
when_to_use: Use when telling someone (or describing someone) to relax or stop being so stressed or upset.

example_1: Okay, spill the tea‚Äîwhat happened at the party?
example_2: She loves to spill the tea about her coworkers.
when_to_use: Use in casual, playful contexts when asking someone to tell you the juicy or interesting details about a situation.

example_1: He kept throwing shade at her outfit.
example_2: The comment seemed harmless, but it was definitely shade.
when_to_use: Use when someone makes a comment that looks neutral but is actually meant as a hidden insult or criticism.

meaning: an impressive transformation in appearance or confidence
example_1: He really had a glow up after high school.
example_2: Her glow up over the last year is amazing.
when_to_use: Use when someone has become noticeably more attractive, stylish, or confident over time.

meaning: show off to impress or intimidate
example_1: He loves to flex on Instagram with his new car.
example_2: She wasn‚Äôt trying to flex on you; she‚Äôs just proud.
when_to_use: Use in casual conversation when someone shows off their success, wealth, or appearance in a way meant to impress others.

meaning: suddenly stop replying or contacting someone
example_1: He ghosted her after the third date.
example_2: Don‚Äôt just ghost people; be honest.
when_to_use: Use when someone ends communication without explanation, especially in dating or friendships.

example_1: I‚Äôm low-key excited about the promotion.
example_2: They want to keep the celebration low-key.
when_to_use: Use for mild or hidden feelings and for events that are meant to be simple and not flashy.

example_1: I high-key love this song.
example_2: He was high-key annoyed by the noise.
when_to_use: Use when you want to emphasize strong feelings or reactions in an open, noticeable way.

meaning: bitter or upset about something minor
example_1: He‚Äôs still salty about losing the game.
example_2: She got salty when no one liked her post.
when_to_use: Use when someone is unreasonably upset or bitter over something small or trivial.

example_1: That entrance was so extra.
example_2: He‚Äôs being extra about a simple mistake.
when_to_use: Use when someone‚Äôs behavior, reaction, or style is overly dramatic or exaggerated beyond what seems necessary.

example_1: I was shook by the plot twist.
example_2: She looked shook when she heard the news.
when_to_use: Use informally when something strongly surprises or emotionally affects you.

meaning: boldly harsh, brutally honest, or impressive
example_1: That comeback was savage.
example_2: She made a savage move in the game.
when_to_use: Use when someone does or says something very bold, harsh, or impressive, often admired in a humorous way.

meaning: sleep at someone‚Äôs home, usually informally
example_1: Can I crash at your place tonight?
example_2: He crashed at my place after the concert.
when_to_use: Use informally when you stay the night at someone's home without much planning or formality.

example_1: Hit me up if you want to hang out.
example_2: Just hit me up later with the details.
when_to_use: Use in casual conversation when inviting someone to contact you later.

example_1: Keep me in the loop about the project.
example_2: She likes to stay in the loop on all decisions.
when_to_use: Use when talking about being included in updates, emails, or decisions, especially in work or group contexts.

example_1: I‚Äôve been out of the loop on office gossip.
example_2: He felt out of the loop after his vacation.
when_to_use: Use when someone is not being updated or included in communication and therefore doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs happening.

meaning: become very upset, scared, or excited
example_1: Don‚Äôt freak out; it‚Äôs just a test.
example_2: She freaked out when she saw the spider.
when_to_use: Use when someone suddenly has a strong emotional reaction‚Äîpositive or negative‚Äîoften visibly.

meaning: do something to release energy or stress
example_1: He went for a run to blow off steam.
example_2: We play video games to blow off steam after work.
when_to_use: Use when someone does an activity (sports, games, etc.) to reduce anger, stress, or tension.

meaning: be exactly what was needed or wanted
example_1: That cold drink really hit the spot.
example_2: A nap would hit the spot right now.
when_to_use: Use when food, drink, rest, or an activity feels exactly right and satisfying at that moment.

example_1: He‚Äôs in hot water with his boss.
example_2: She got in hot water for missing the deadline.
when_to_use: Use when someone is facing criticism, punishment, or serious problems, often because of something they did.

meaning: cause trouble or disturb a stable situation
example_1: I don‚Äôt want to rock the boat by complaining.
example_2: His comments rocked the boat at the meeting.
when_to_use: Use when someone says or does something that may cause conflict or disrupt a stable situation.

phrase: hit the nail on the head
example_1: Your explanation hit the nail on the head.
example_2: She hit the nail on the head about our problem.
when_to_use: Use when someone perfectly captures the truth, cause, or solution of a situation.

example_1: Another old laptop bit the dust today.
example_2: Several proposals bit the dust before we agreed.
when_to_use: Use playfully when something fails, ends, or breaks‚Äîoften about objects or attempts, sometimes about people in jokes.

meaning: try very hard to help or please
example_1: They bent over backwards to make us comfortable.
example_2: She bent over backwards to meet the deadline.
when_to_use: Use when someone makes a lot of effort, often more than is necessary, to help or please others.

example_1: Don‚Äôt burn bridges when leaving a job.
example_2: He burned his bridges with that angry email.
when_to_use: Use when someone behaves in a way that will prevent them from going back to a person, job, or situation in the future.

example_1: Dad hit the ceiling when he saw the mess.
example_2: She hit the ceiling over the budget cuts.
when_to_use: Use when someone suddenly becomes very angry, often loudly or dramatically.

example_1: She was on cloud nine after the promotion.
example_2: He‚Äôs been on cloud nine since the baby arrived.
when_to_use: Use when someone feels extremely happy, often after good news or a big positive event.

example_1: They‚Äôre going through a rough patch in their marriage.
example_2: We hit a rough patch financially last year.
when_to_use: Use when describing a temporary period of difficulty in relationships, finances, health, or life in general.

example_1: He‚Äôs been down in the dumps all week.
example_2: Rainy weather makes me feel down in the dumps.
when_to_use: Use when someone feels very sad, unmotivated, or emotionally low, especially for a short period.

meaning: slow down or stop what you're doing
example_1: We need to hit the brakes on spending.
example_2: He hit the brakes on the project after feedback.
when_to_use: Use when you decide to slow or stop progress on something like plans, spending, or a project.

example_1: He realized he was in over his head with that class.
example_2: She felt in over her head at the new job.
when_to_use: Use when someone is dealing with a situation that is more complex or difficult than they can manage.

example_1: Try to keep your cool during the interview.
example_2: He kept his cool even under pressure.
when_to_use: Use when advising someone to remain calm in a stressful or emotional situation.

example_1: Take a breath and pull yourself together.
example_2: She pulled herself together before the speech.
when_to_use: Use when someone needs to stop panicking or crying and regain emotional control to keep going.

example_1: Take it easy this weekend.
example_2: The doctor told him to take it easy after surgery.
when_to_use: Use when telling someone to relax, avoid stress, or not work too hard, often for health or rest.

example_1: We sat on the porch and shot the breeze.
example_2: They love to shoot the breeze after work.
when_to_use: Use when people are talking in a relaxed, informal way about everyday, not serious topics.

meaning: act too soon, before the right time
example_1: We jumped the gun by announcing it early.
example_2: Don‚Äôt jump the gun on the decision.
when_to_use: Use when someone does something before they have enough information or before it‚Äôs appropriate.

example_1: She hit the jackpot with that scholarship.
example_2: We hit the jackpot finding this apartment.
when_to_use: Use when someone experiences very good fortune or success, especially unexpectedly or beyond expectations.

example_1: Mind if I take a rain check on dinner?
example_2: I‚Äôll have to take a rain check; I‚Äôm busy tonight.
when_to_use: Use when you decline an invitation for now but want to suggest doing it at a later time.

meaning: agreeing or having the same understanding
example_1: We need to be on the same page before the meeting.
example_2: They weren‚Äôt on the same page about priorities.
when_to_use: Use when people have the same idea or understanding about a plan, goal, or situation.

meaning: experience sudden great success or luck
example_1: He hit the jackpot investing early.
example_2: They hit the jackpot with their new product.
when_to_use: Use when someone gains a lot of money, success, or advantage in a short time, often unexpectedly.

example_1: It took me a while to wrap my head around the new system.
example_2: She‚Äôs still wrapping her head around the news.
when_to_use: Use when you‚Äôre trying to understand complex information or surprising news.

example_1: I‚Äôm in a bit of a pickle with this schedule.
example_2: He found himself in a pickle after missing the train.
when_to_use: Use (often lightly or humorously) when someone is in a difficult or inconvenient situation.

meaning: in a risky or dangerous situation
example_1: You‚Äôre on thin ice with your boss.
example_2: He knew he was on thin ice after the mistake.
when_to_use: Use when someone is close to getting in serious trouble if they make another mistake.

meaning: be in control or make the decisions
example_1: She‚Äôs the one who calls the shots in the team.
example_2: The manager calls the shots on hiring.
when_to_use: Use when talking about the person who has the power or authority to make important decisions.

example_1: He works well under pressure.
example_2: We‚Äôre under pressure to finish by Friday.
when_to_use: Use when someone is dealing with deadlines, expectations, or stressful responsibilities.

example_1: I‚Äôm on the fence about moving.
example_2: She‚Äôs on the fence about the job offer.
when_to_use: Use when someone has not yet chosen between two or more options and is still thinking.
